summary: The total paid-up share capital of DSQ Industries Ltd. was Rs. 20,04,29,160 consisting of 2,00,42,916 shares of Rs. 10/10/10 . It was noticed that there were discrepancies in the distribution schedule filed by the company with the CSE and with SEBI .  An associate of Shri Harish Biyani entered into cross deals also. between 2 brokers – namely Shri . Harish . Hari Hari and Amritlal Gopalji Thacker . Thacker placed a buy order no. 180721378 at 14.52.17 hrs for 100 shares @ Rs. 366 when the last traded price was Rs. 363.8.8 .  Trading was concentrated among 3 brokers namely Shri Harish Biyani, Niraj Kumar Balasaria and Amritlal Gopalji Thacker . There was creation of artificial market and artificial volumes as a result of synchronization of logging in / matching of buy and sell orders amongst few brokers .  Shares were brought in synchronised deals with buying and selling orders logged in at almost the same time for same rate and quantity with prior understanding to match sell orders with specific buy orders . Shares effectively did not change beneficial ownership by remaining within DSQ group .  Biyani Securities Pvt. Ltd. sold as empanelled broker a total of 10.4 lakh shares of DSQ . The buy and sell orders were placed in close proximity of time 5-15 seconds . Investigations brought out that the off market transfer of 3,00,000 shares was from the demat account of Square D Textiles – a DSQ group entity .  The contentions by Biyani Securities Pvt. Ltd. that they sold 1.7 lakh shares on behalf of DSQ group entity – Hulda is not tenable . Many of the buying clients as above have same address as that of ‘Hulda’ and also Mr Bhalotia as common director in Hulda . The order log and trade log revealed that there was synchronization of orders .  Shri Harish Biyani used shares of DSQ Industries for availing finance in the ‘sell and cash’ scheme of SHCIL by selling shares as empanelled broker . These shares were credited as off market purchases and were credited from the demat account of Hulda . CSE had subsequently expunged the transaction of 2,40,000 shares amounting to Rs 8.04 crore on the grounds that the transactions were non genuine .  Shri Harish Biyani requested SHCIL to sell 2.4 lakh shares of DSQ Industries Ltd under ‘sell-n-cash’ scheme . Under this scheme the payment is released one day after the pay out of the relevant 4.19 .  The transactions done by Biyani group of brokers in the ‘sell n cash’ scheme of SCHIL on 27/2/01 and 1/3/01 are strong pointer to the promoter broker nexus between DSQ Group and Biyaani group . The transactions also created artificial market, creation of artificial volumes as a result of synchronization of buy and sell orders .  In appeal no – Nirmal Bang Securities Pvt. Ltd vs. SEBI, the Hon’ble Securities Appellate Tribunal has held as under with regard to “BEB has been charged for synchronized deals with First Global.”  Biyani Securities Pvt. Ltd. sold 7.2 lac shares of DSQ Industries, Shri Harish Biyan purchased 2.2 . Lived in a series of irregular transactions by way of synchronized trades and cross deals .  Problem at CSE was building up of large outstanding positions by few brokers in few scrips mainly in HFCL and DSQ and volatility in the prices .  The strict rules of Evidence Act and proof beyond reasonable doubt are not applicable to a proceeding of this nature . The Supreme Court’s decision in Gulabchand vs. Kudilal AIR, 1966, SC 1734 is relied upon in this regard .

summary: Appeal dismissed . Appellate Tribunal found that the assessees had agreed to pay off the decree a1nount from the remuneration due to them . Assessees' counsel argued, relying on the case cf Mitchell Mitchell Mitchell, impropriety of-Business expenditnre- Payments to avoid disclosure of misfeasance of director .  An appeal from the High Court at Calcutta (Harries C.J. and Chatterjea J.) pronounced on a reference made to it by the Income.tax Tribunal under section 66 (2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 . Held, that the High. Court acted wrongly in accepting the argurr1ents of the assessees' counsel as if they were proved facts .  The Calcutta Agency Ltd. instituted four suits in High Court being suit Nos. 1683, 1720, 1735 and for the said aggregate sum of Rs. 1,80,000 and the interest thereon . The Tribunal rejected that argument and the High Court also rejected the same .  Mills Ltd. agreed to Kania o. J. deduct certain amounts from the managing agency commission and therefore such expenditure came with- in section 10(2) (xv) of the Act . Chatterjea J. observed as follows as follows:-"In this case it is clear that the agreement was entered into with a view to avoid publicity of an action against the Mana- ging agents and consequent exposure and scandal"  Court differed from the conclusion of the Tribunal and allowed the deduction to the respondent company under section 10(2) (xv) of the Income-tax Act . Ka1ita C. J, assailed on the ground that there was no evidence for the conclusions on facts recorded by the Tribunal . It is therefore the duty of the High Court to look at the facts found by the tribunal and answer the questions of law on that footing .  The contention was that this sum should be treated as not having become the income of the assessee at all because it was deducted at the source by the Mill company . No evidence, it appears, was led before the Income Tax Tribunal, nor has the Tribunal recorded any findings of fact on which the principles laid down in Mitchell's case(') could be applied .
